scope: Audit of KPLC Annual Financial Statements for the year ended 30 June 2024 in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISA) and IFRS.
executiveSummary: KPMG audit of FY2024 financial statements in progress. Interim procedures completed. Focus areas include power purchase cost accruals, trade receivables provisioning, and capital works in progress.

findings.description: Power purchase cost accruals as at June 2024 require additional vendor confirmations.

scope: Audit of KPLC Annual Financial Statements for the year ended 30 June 2023. Includes review of related party transactions with KenGen, Kenya Electricity Transmission Company (KETRACO), and REA.
executiveSummary: Deloitte issued an unqualified opinion with an emphasis of matter paragraph on related party transactions totalling KES 42bn with KenGen. IFRS 16 lease accounting treatment verified. All 2022 audit management letter recommendations implemented.

findings.description: Enhanced disclosure on nature and terms of KenGen Power Purchase Agreement recommended.
Unbilled revenue estimation methodology requires recalibration to post-COVID consumption patterns.

scope: Review of revenue management controls covering billing accuracy, collection processes, meter tampering detection, and revenue protection operations for H1 FY2024.
executiveSummary: Internal audit identified 12 high-priority findings. Key issues: (1) CIS system unpatched since March 2023 creating cybersecurity vulnerability; (2) 1,240 commercial accounts with revenue discrepancies totalling KES 85m; (3) Revenue protection teams covering only 60% of high-risk areas.

findings.description: CIS unpatched since March 2023 — 3 critical CVEs identified. Risk of billing data breach.
1,240 commercial accounts with unexplained revenue discrepancies of KES 85m.
Revenue protection field operations covering only 60% of high-risk areas.

scope: Compliance audit of procurement processes for contracts above KES 50m awarded in FY2023/24 Q1, covering PPRA compliance, competitive tendering, and contract management.
executiveSummary: 14 contracts reviewed totalling KES 3.8bn. 2 high-risk findings: one contract awarded without required PPRA approval and one contract with scope creep increasing value by 42% without competitive re-bidding. 4 medium-risk findings on documentation.

findings.description: Contract for meter procurement KES 850m awarded without mandatory PPRA approval.
Distribution line contract scope increased 42% without competitive re-bidding.

scope: Annual EPRA compliance inspection covering technical standards compliance, quality of supply (voltage levels, frequency), customer service standards, and licence condition compliance.
executiveSummary: EPRA inspection rated KPLC overall compliance as Satisfactory. SAIDI performance noted as requiring improvement (38 hours vs. 35-hour standard). Customer complaint resolution timelines within acceptable range. Revenue protection activities assessed as adequate.

findings.description: SAIDI of 38 hours exceeds 35-hour minimum standard. KPLC directed to submit improvement plan.
Fault clearance response time in Mombasa North region averaging 8.2 hours vs 6-hour standard.

scope: External penetration testing and vulnerability assessment of KPLC core IT systems including CIS, ERP (FINESSE), SCADA, and network infrastructure.
executiveSummary: 4 critical vulnerabilities identified: (1) CIS unpatched CVEs enabling potential remote code execution; (2) SCADA network accessible from corporate LAN without proper segmentation; (3) Default credentials on 3 substation SCADA RTUs; (4) Insufficient MFA on remote access VPN. Immediate remediation required.

findings.description: CIS unpatched — 3 critical CVEs enabling remote code execution on billing server.
SCADA network not segmented from corporate LAN — potential for OT network attack.

scope: Audit of Kenya Airways Plc Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2023 including Group and Company statements, IFRS 16 lease liabilities, and going concern assessment.
executiveSummary: EY issued a modified opinion with emphasis of matter on going concern. Net loss of KES 3.8bn and negative equity of KES 36bn noted. 5 high-risk audit findings including revenue leakage in code-share settlements and jet fuel cost accrual discrepancies. Government letter of support obtained for going concern note.

findings.description: Negative equity KES 36bn and continued losses require going concern emphasis. Government support letter obtained.
Code-share settlement revenue leakage estimated KES 320m — reconciliation controls inadequate.
Jet fuel cost accrual at year-end understated by KES 85m.

scope: IATA Operational Safety Audit (IOSA) biennial renewal covering flight operations, cabin operations, ground operations, dispatch, maintenance, security, and cargo operations.
executiveSummary: Kenya Airways retained IOSA registration for 2024-2026 period. 3 findings raised — all categorised as Findings (not Observations). KQ issued corrective action plans within required 30 days. IOSA renewal critical for maintaining codeshare agreements with SkyTeam partners.

findings.description: Documentation gap in minimum equipment list (MEL) for B737-800 series — update required.
Cargo dangerous goods training records incomplete for 18 handlers.

scope: Review of KQ MRO expenditure for FY2023 covering heavy maintenance contracts, parts procurement, and component pooling agreements with MRO providers.
executiveSummary: MRO costs totalling KES 7.1bn reviewed. 4 medium-risk findings: (1) KES 850m in uncompetitively tendered parts from approved vendors; (2) Component loan agreements resulting in KES 280m in avoidable fees; (3) Workshop labour rate benchmarking showing 12% premium vs market. Overall MRO governance rated Moderate.

findings.description: KES 850m parts procurement without competitive tender from preferred vendors.
Component loan fees of KES 280m avoidable with improved stock management.

scope: Audit of Kenya Airways Plc Consolidated Financial Statements for year ended 31 December 2022.
executiveSummary: EY issued modified opinion with going concern emphasis. FY2022 net loss KES 5.2bn, negative equity KES 36bn. Government equity injection KES 15bn correctly classified. Key risk areas: IFRS 16 lease modification accounting for COVID-era lease deferrals.

findings.description: Continued negative equity and losses. Going concern emphasis required.
IFRS 16 lease modification accounting for COVID-era deferrals required restatement.

scope: KCAA Line Station inspection at JKIA covering ramp operations, aircraft documentation compliance, crew briefing facilities, and fuelling procedures.
executiveSummary: KCAA line station inspection at JKIA completed with 2 minor findings. Aircraft documentation compliance satisfactory. Crew briefing facilities below standard specification — upgrade required within 90 days.

findings.description: Crew briefing room size below KCAA minimum specification for 250-seat aircraft operations.

scope: Audit of KPA Annual Financial Statements for year ended 30 June 2024, including revenue recognition for berth charges, pilotage fees, and storage charges; review of Berths 21-24 asset capitalisation.
executiveSummary: FY2024 audit in progress. Interim audit procedures completed. No significant issues identified to date. Berths 21-24 KES 18.2bn asset capitalisation review ongoing.

scope: Audit of KPA Annual Financial Statements for year ended 30 June 2023. Includes review of KES 10.1bn Berths 21-24 capital work in progress and KRA disputed tax assessment provisioning.
executiveSummary: PwC issued clean unqualified opinion. KPA FY2023 results: revenue KES 40.5bn, net profit KES 8.2bn — strongest performance in KPA's history. KRA disputed tax assessment of KES 420m adequately disclosed as contingent liability. No material weaknesses in internal controls.

findings.description: KRA disputed assessment of KES 420m to be disclosed as contingent liability per IAS 37.

scope: Compliance audit of procurement processes for Q1 and Q2 FY2023/24 including Navis N4 TOS procurement, crane procurement contracts, and direct procurement exemptions.
executiveSummary: 8 contracts reviewed totalling KES 6.8bn. 8 medium-risk findings mainly on documentation completeness and approval matrix compliance. Overall procurement governance rated Adequate. No evidence of fraud or corrupt practices. Navis N4 TOS procurement followed correct competitive process.

findings.description: 3 contracts missing signed vendor performance evaluation forms post-award.
2 direct procurement exemptions did not receive MD approval as required by KPA Procurement Policy.

scope: Annual environmental compliance audit covering MARPOL waste reception facility compliance, Kilindini Harbour water quality monitoring, dust management from bulk cargo operations, and mangrove replanting at Lamu.
executiveSummary: KPA's environmental compliance rated Moderate. Key finding: Kilindini Harbour water quality at 3 monitoring points shows elevated total dissolved solids from bunkering operations. Waste reception facility capacity needs upgrading. Lamu mangrove replanting programme on track — 15,000 of 18,000 target trees planted.

findings.description: Kilindini Harbour TDS levels elevated at 3 monitoring points — above NEMA water quality guidelines.
Waste reception facility at capacity — upgrade required per MARPOL Annex V obligations.

scope: Forensic investigation into code-share settlement revenue leakage identified by Ernst & Young during FY2023 audit. Scope covers Air France-KLM, Delta, and Ethiopian Airlines prorate settlements 2020-2023.
executiveSummary: Forensic investigation confirmed revenue leakage of KES 285m (slightly below EY estimate of KES 320m). Root cause: outdated prorate settlement rules in Amadeus Altéa not updated after route changes. No fraud identified — systems error. KQ raised formal claims with AF-KLM (KES 162m) and Ethiopian Airlines (KES 78m). Delta settlement agreed (KES 45m).

findings.description: Altéa prorate rules not updated for 14 route changes since 2020 — revenue leakage KES 285m.
Monthly settlement reconciliation process not performed as per GDS operations manual.

scope: Audit of KPLC Annual Financial Statements for the year ended 30 June 2022.
executiveSummary: Deloitte issued unqualified opinion. FY2022 revenue KES 54.2bn, net profit KES 2.1bn. Focus areas: deferred power purchase costs (regulatory asset) — KES 8.2bn balance; Last Mile Connectivity Project expenditure capitalisation; IFRS 16 compliance for network leases.

findings.description: LMCP capitalisation policy requires clearer criteria distinguishing capital vs operational expenditure.

scope: Value for money audit on Berths 21-24 construction project, assessing procurement process, project management, cost control, and planned benefits realisation.
executiveSummary: OAG Performance Audit rated Berths 21-24 project as Generally Satisfactory. Project delivered broadly on time (2 months delay) and on budget (96% cost utilisation). Procurement followed correct procedures. OAG raised concerns on consultant appointment without public tender and project supervision gaps during COVID-19.

findings.description: Project management consultant appointed by direct procurement — KES 420m value should have required open tender.
Supervision gaps identified during March–September 2021 COVID period. Site engineer reports incomplete.

scope: Occupational Health and Safety Management System audit of KPLC field operations, distribution centres, and substations for ISO 45001:2018 compliance.
executiveSummary: KPLC OH&S compliance rated Adequate. 6 non-conformances identified: (1) PPE usage compliance at 72% (target 100%); (2) Safety induction incomplete for 340 contractors; (3) 2 substations with outdated emergency response plans. Machine guarding satisfactory in 95% of reviewed locations.

findings.description: PPE compliance rate 72% against 100% target — primarily an enforcement issue in distribution depots.
340 active contractors with incomplete KPLC site safety induction records.

scope: Review of KQ payroll controls, allowance entitlements, and HR data accuracy for all staff categories (pilots, cabin crew, ground staff, administration).
executiveSummary: Payroll audit of 4,200 employees. 3 low-risk findings: (1) 45 terminated employees still receiving allowances totalling KES 2.8m; (2) 12 staff with dual employment records; (3) Overtime approval controls require tightening. Overall payroll governance rated Good.

findings.description: 45 terminated employees receiving allowances — KES 2.8m to be recovered.
12 staff with duplicate HRMS records — data cleansing required.

scope: IT security audit of Port Community System Phase 1 (existing TOS) covering access controls, user authentication, data integrity, and network security.
executiveSummary: PCS Phase 1 security audit identified 2 medium-risk findings: (1) 8 dormant user accounts with active system access; (2) PCS admin credentials shared between 3 operators. No critical vulnerabilities found. Data integrity controls rated Satisfactory. Audit supports Navis N4 upgrade decision.

findings.description: 8 dormant PCS user accounts with active access — deactivation required.
PCS admin credentials shared between 3 operators — individual accounts required.

scope: Audit of KPA Annual Financial Statements for year ended 30 June 2022.
executiveSummary: PwC issued clean unqualified opinion. FY2022 revenue KES 38.2bn, net profit KES 7.1bn. Revenue recognition policies reviewed — berth and pilotage charges correctly recognised on completion of service. Berths 21-24 KES 6.8bn CWIP appropriately carried.

scope: VFM audit of KPLC's Last Mile Connectivity Project Phase III covering procurement efficiency, connections quality, cost per connection, and beneficiary satisfaction.
executiveSummary: OAG VFM audit rated LMCP Phase III as Satisfactory. Average cost per connection of KES 43,000 within acceptable range. 97% of sampled connections (n=500) found to be energised and functional. However, 8% of connections did not have service agreements in place. Meter bypass by 4% of new customers noted.

findings.description: 8% of LMCP connections (approx. 18,000) completed without signed service agreements.
Meter bypass by approximately 4% of new LMCP customers representing KES 185m annual revenue loss.

scope: Audit of Kenya Airways Plc for year ended 31 December 2021.
executiveSummary: EY issued modified going concern opinion. FY2021 net loss KES 8.6bn — worst year in KQ history. Negative equity KES 35bn. COVID-19 provisions and aircraft impairments of KES 4.8bn reviewed and confirmed adequate. Government letter of support obtained.

findings.description: Net loss KES 8.6bn and negative equity KES 35bn require going concern modification.

scope: Review of KPA equipment management, maintenance records, crane certification, and disposal of life-expired equipment including 3 STS cranes beyond 25-year design life.
executiveSummary: Equipment audit identified critical risk: 3 STS gantry cranes (Cranes 4, 7, and 11) operating beyond design life with increasing defect rates. Crane 4 had 18 breakdowns in FY2024 — average 12 hours downtime per breakdown. Emergency crane replacement programme recommended for FY2025/26 capital budget at estimated KES 3.8bn for 3 replacements.

findings.description: 3 STS cranes beyond 25-year design life with increasing failure rates — replacement urgently required.
Crane 4 major defect report (MDR) frequency of 18 times in FY2024 — above acceptable 4 per year safety threshold.
